Message.Msg: Oh my this is not good. 2014 is like forever. Technology moves fast and Samsung and others will dominate China and other emerging markets by then. Cook needs to do something now, not 2014. “Apple reportedly has a completely redesigned low-end iPhone in the works set to launch some time next year,” Zach Epstein reports for BGR. “Japanese blog Macotakara, which has reported accurate details surrounding unannounced Apple products in the past, claims that this new iPhone will feature a polycarbonate body,” Epstein reports. “The new handset will supposedly feature a larger 4.5-inch display and will be slightly thicker than current iPhone models as well”

Message.Title: Dramatic Growth Slowdown Seen For Smartphones..
Message.Msg: The global market is certainly expanding quickly but not that fast. Between 2010 and 2011, total global shipments increased 64%, according to research firm Strategy Analytics. In 2012, the pace of shipment growth slowed to 43% year-on- year. In 2013, growth is expected to slow down further to 36%, Strategy Analytics says.

Topic.Title: TC and the AAPL BOD still think they are a growth story

Message.Msg: That's not what Tim Cook said re. "cash". He closed the stockholder's meeting sayiing "the board is seriously considering what to do with Apple's excess cash". This means they will either raise the dividend or initiate a bigger stock buyback program, most think. And yes, he thinks Apple will still grow, although slower in the past. But Apple's even rapid growth in recent years has not consumed much cash, as they don't need to build factories, rather they subcontract out production much more cheaply by Chinese Companies paying $1 to $2 an hour, than building new expensive factories in USA with UAW labor as say GM does.

Message.Title: Speculations About Apple's Future Growth and Profits
Message.Msg: There are many speculating that Apple's growth and profits will decline since the bigger growth going forward is in Emerging Markets countries, and there its unlikely Apple can get 40 - 50% of the markets as it has in higher wage USA, Canada, Australia...etc. While indeed Apple's Revenues Growth declined last quarter to only 18% (27% if you believe the 13 weeks vs. 14 weeks prior year's quarter), nonetheless its Profits grew a bit above the prior year's record high levels. What this proves is that even though Apple grew slower last quarter than the overall smartphone market's growth in 2012, it still was able to generate great profits and amazing highest ever CashFlow of $23 Billion (before paying out div.) So even though Apple probably can't ever get 40% of most emerging markets share, if it can simply grow from 4% of India's market and 8% of China's market to now to say 15% (as it has in Japan), along with those markets growing fast, it still will increase sales and profits alot.

Message.Title: BMO Capital Sees Q2 iPhone 5 Estimates At Grave Risk
Message.Msg: March 1, 2013 7:56 AM EST BMO Capital Less Sanguine on Apple (AAPL) Following Mobile World Congress; 'Absolutely' Needs Larger Screen iPhone BMO Capital analyst Keith Bachman said he came away from the Mobile World Congress modestly more negative on Apple (NASDAQ: AAPL) after speaking with carriers that serve Europe, Latin America, and the Middle East; and 2) a distributor that serves the Middle East. "In aggregating the comments, people we spoke with mentioned that the iPhone 5 is a good device that gets interest, but is not materially different from the iPhone 4S," he said. "In particular, Samsung's products such as the Galaxy S3, seem to be generating much greater interest. Many thought that Apple needed a large screen size product." In one example, Bachman said store managers in Barcelona mentioned that Apple was getting much less interest than other handsets, and named Samsung as the most popular device. The analyst said his estimate of 37.8 million iPhones in March, and 34.5 million in the June and 18 million iPads in March and 19 million in the June, are "reasonable" but he sees more downside tension than upside tension, particularly for iPhones.

Message.Title: Market may drop 300pt a day: TradeUP these:TZA EDZ UVXY
Price Competition Low End Smartphones Nothing New
Message.Msg: Nokia was at low end and lost market share to others. HTC offered $0 down 4G Android Smarthphones in 2010, and has not done well in profits since. I know, i bought one for $0 down, and 4G in 2010 was better spec. (though not better software) than Apple offered. Yet Apple still managed to grow its sales and make good and growing profits. Apple has managed to grow its sales fast in Japan and China, despite being the higher priced smartphone, and make good profits doing so (though only got 8 - 15% of market share). THE LOW PRICED END OF THE MARKET DOESN'T MAKE MONEY, THIS IS NOTHING NEW. Apple managed to carve out a big part of the higher end for itself, and so made good profits. Its the old 80/20 rule, the top 20% of a market is where 80% of the profits are. Apple doesn't need to be competitive at the low-end of the market: let many Android phone makers fight that out.

Message.Msg: iPhone pressures NT, optimistic LT; Lowering Estimates  Lowering estimates, retain Outperform. We lower our EPS estimates for Apple by 6%/7% for FY13/FY14 to $44.9/$54.0 driven principally by lower iPhone shipments. We reiterate our Outperform rating as we believe this is more of a reset instead of secular pressure on the business, and remain of the view that product refresh in 2HFY13 will return Apple to its growing ways.  iPhone now looking for units of 30.6mn in Q2CY13 driven by three factors. For iPhone, we lower our volume estimates by 11%/8% to 158mn/194mn for CY13/CY14 due to following reasons: 1) We are factoring the likelihood of an iPhone refresh for mid-2013, which will cause a hesitancy effect on demand and cause Apple to keep the supply chain lean; 2) Simultaneously we believe the Samsung Galaxy S4 will launch in mid-March and is likely to gain share in the high-end; and 3) At MWC (see our note published today for details), we see over 35 smartphone launches from leading OEMs year to date, of which ~70% are aimed at the high-end and ~60% have a screen size larger than iPhone 5 (of over 4"), thereby narrowing the product lead on hardware side.  iPhone remains a growth business. We would view the above reduction in volume forecasts as a reset and product transition impact rather than a structural concern long term. We still expect iPhone volumes to grow 16%/23% in CY13/CY14 driving revenue growth of 10%/19% in iPhone business. First, we believe carrier expansion could add a further 65mn units to iPhone volumes, the timing of which is hard to predict but likelihood remains high. Second, a low-end iPhone, which is not currently assumed within our estimates, could prove meaningfully additive. Third, we believe that Apple may have a narrower lead on the hardware than in the past, however it still retains an ecosystem advantage.  Valuation. Apple trades on 8x our CY14 EPS, which is inexpensive given 11% growth we expect CY12-CY14 and net cash/share of $145

Message.Title: iDash
Message.Msg: iDash is software for the newest frontier in computing on the Mac: the car. While OS X does have one of the best user interfaces among all of the operating systems out there, its pretty difficult (not to mention dangerous) to use while driving down the road. iDash is a frontend that is able to control almost any applications via a plugin written Applescript. Thus enabling the intigration of music, movie and photo collections as well as GPS & Radio features into an easy to use all-in-one application. The project was started by Ryan Green in mid January of 2005, since then the development team has quickly grown and are projecting an initial alpha release in mid-march.

Message.Title: The Last 6 Times Tim Cook Has Talked, Apple's Stock Has Dropped
Message.Msg: On Wednesday afternoon, Apple CEO Tim Cook addressed investors and the media at the company's annual shareholders meeting. It was the sixth time in the last five months that Cook has made something like a public appearance; and it is also the sixth time in the past five months that Apple's stock (AAPL) has closed down after Cook appeared. Consider this: The last six times that Cook has put himself out there, Apple's stock declined afterwards. It's a streak that dates back to October 2012, when Cook introduced the iPad mini, and it is a trend that has gone unbroken for about five months now: When Cook appears, AAPL goes down Here are the six appearances, and the AAPL reaction: 1. Annual Shareholder's Meeting, 2/27/2013 Open: $448.43 Close: $444.57 2. Goldman Sachs Technology Conference, 2/12/2012 Open: $479.51 Close: $467.90 3. Apple Q1 Earnings Call, 1/24/2013 (after hours) Open: $451.69 Close: $439.88 4. "Bloomberg Businessweek" cover story/appearance on "Rock Center with Brian Williams" (after hours), 12/07/2012 Open: $553.40 Close: $533.25 5. Apple Q4 Earnings Call, 10/25/2012 (after hours) Open: $620.00 Close: $609.54 6. iPad Mini Event, 10/23/2012 Open: $631.36 Close: $613.36

Message.Title: iPad Mini Killing it!
Message.Msg: Pad mini helping Apple grow its lead in mobile ad impressions to third of market By Kevin Bostic Apple in 2012 increased its lead over other mobile device manufacturers in terms of mobile ad impressions, leveraging the launch of the iPad mini to grow its share to nearly a third of the overall market, according to a new statistics. Millennial Media, the third-largest mobile advertising platform after Apple and Google, released on Friday its 2012 year in review report for the mobile advertising market, which places Apple atop all other manufacturers with 31.2% of all mobile-based ad impressions. That's nearly a five%age point increase over the company's 26.35% share in 2011. More specifically, the report illustrates the increasing dominance of Apple and Samsung in the mobile sector. see full article on ai

Message.Title: Are retail investors afraid to get back into Apple?
Message.Msg: What do the longs have to say? Have so many retail investors taken such a hit over the last 4-5 months, that they have gone elsewhere with such a bad taste in their mouth that they don't want to risk coming back to Apple? Maybe so many bought in well under where we are now, (I'm one) and they have gotten out at some point as the stock was falling. Saying thank-you, and moving on to something else, or doing something with the profits? (I'm still long) Maybe retail investors are all small time compared to the large funds that hold apple, and does not matter what we do. The funds have sold out some of their position, and are looking at other stocks these days. (maybe its not hip to own apple now. Specially with such a pull back) Or maybe so many people don't see the huge growth that happened over from mid 2011 to mid 2012 happening again, and have moved on. I'm probably pretty typical. (maybe I'm one of the lucky ones....) I bought in at 1/2 where we are now. Held through the high, and am still holding, (and bought in more) but of course wished I had known when to get out. Still holding because I see this company that just keeps "printing money" every quarter. iPhone/iPad sales up / down a bit. Does this really matte?. Look at the profit they are making. What if they ONLY made half that profit. Would that really be such a bad thing? ! I don't see any indication that Apple is about to close up shop any time soon. They are not done feeding us their cool-aid, and a pretty loyal following ready to buy up the next gadget. Some need to wait till their current contract is up with their carrier before its upgrade time. But so many will replace their IOS device with another IOS device. (I bought into a iPhone 4S in Nov of 2011. 2 year contract. So I still have 8 months on a current contract. iPhone 4S sales were so strong, I'm not alone on this particular upgrade cycle) I can't believe were are trading at $440 for this stock. $550 or even $650 seems more realistic.

Message.Title: OMG, Getting Dangerously Close to $435
Message.Msg: Apple needs to stay above 435 before higher dividends/more buyback news. Let's hope the buy buttons are working in Cupertino to shore up the stock price. Otherwise, this really could be look out below. If it does fall below the critical point (it's actually 425-435, but - IMO - as soon as it breaches 435, panic will set in), I put the blame squarely on Tim Cook. I get he's got his mission and is not a motivational speaker, but he owes it to the shareholder to communicate something INTELLIGENT & STRONG, with the sole goal of regaining the market's confidence in Apple. How about: "We at Apple know our cash position is extremely high. We have every intention of returning that cash to the shareholder while simultaneously investing in our next transformational product. As you all know, matters of dividends and buybacks all need to be voted on by the board, and we, therefore, will need to wait for this voting before any announcements can be made"....as opposed to TC's "very, very active discussions on cash distribution". My suggested copy would get a 10% bump in share price before actually announcing the dividend/buyback.

Message.Title: Here is the reality at the AT&T stores. (Survey 5 stores) iPhones sales
Message.Msg: Apple iPhones account for 50 - 65% of smartphone activations..... Over 85% of current iPhone users upgrade to iPhones. A steady market share for the last several months. Those who switch, the majority go to Samsung for larger screen and bigger keypad. The salesforce is inclined to push, and is successful with the iPhone 4S. The reps see no real movement of young buyers away from Apple iPhones. No real switch in demographics. These stores have not been hurt by Walmart offering Apple products, as Walmart has not had continuous stock, especially during launches and holiday seasons. The reps and customers like the simplicity of the iPhone, and find the window phones too complicated, but once people learn how to use the window phones, they like them. Sales of window phones are insignificant. The most interesting comment was from one manager who switched back to an IPhone , from a Samsung, not because he liked the IPhone better, but he recently bought an AirMac , and wanted to have all his stuff on the Eco system. He said several customers have done the same. The macs are driving iPhone sales. Lower Mac prices could drive higher pad and iPhone sales. Bottom line .... Apple is holding its own, young people are buying, but competition is increasing. Ease of use and reliability are the key selling points. A larger screen would be a plus to a small percentage of the customer base, but if the apps for larger keypads get better , that could also work.

Topic.Title: PE Under 10

Message.Msg: Unfortunately, retail investors don't buy PEs; they buy share price. At $435, Apple's price tag is too high for them. With institutional investors jumping (or having already jumped), we need to attract the retail investor. Best way to do that would be a 4 for 1 stock split, a 35% dividend increase and an increased buyback program. Under this scenario, think of a $110 stock paying a 3.5% return ---- that's doable for a lot of retail investors.

Message.Title: Apple Stores - Sales. Survey 10 stores
Message.Msg: Sales are strong, especially for stores with foreign buyers who ship product back to relatives. Most reps like the 4s. Large increase in teacher, student, and business people buying macs and iPads. Large % of first time buyers of pads and macs. Mini is the home run..... iPhone sales remain solid. IOS is well received, iTunes complaints are minimal. Employees like working for Apple, good pay, benefits, and they love the products..... Tim Cook is an enigma, the employees feel he is a great guy, cares, is kind, but most feel he is not a product guy.... Very interesting. Bottom line........ Sales are fine........ A tech Culture at the top needs to be defined.... Infrastructure is strong, just needs new products and technology to keep it going. Stores are significantly underplayed as an asset. All the stores visited in the last two weeks, at mid-day were very busy..... Mostly adults...

Message.Title: An emotional board today
Message.Msg: It seems pretty simple to me. You have 2 choices. 1. You believe that Apple will continue to bring new products to market and that will produce a growing earnings stream. In this case it is a long term buy. 2. You believe that Apple's earnings stream will continue to decline and they will not find a way to increase earnings. In that case it is a sell. You must remember that Tim Cook was hand picked by Steve Jobs; so, it would be very difficult for the BOD to fire him so quickly. My view is that you wait and see what happens in the next 5-6 months. My guess is that we will get a dividend increase. We will also hear about selling a cheaper Iphone model for the Chinese market. The Itv is coming and I've heard that Apple has 100 people working on an Iwristwatch. Let's give it a little time, and if they don't come through, we all should sell in 6 months good luck

Topic.Title: Apple should buy Disney (content provider) and charge a monthly subscription fee

Message.Msg: I agree Disney is pricey given it is at an All Time high, however its forward P/E of 14x is not terrible and the American population has shown a growing love of Beer and Sports, hence ESPN should continue to drive revenue growth. Firm could be acquired for $125B (28% premium to market cap) with Apple having $12B cash left over (ignoring the cash earned since Jan. 1st). Also, the purchase could be funded with 40% debt at a long term rate of 3.5%. That would take 75B out of the cash pile, leaving $62B leftover (ignoring cash earned since Jan. 1st). Management has proven to be great operators of the existing firm, but where is the vision for next 20 years. Surely cannot innovate new hardware every year, too difficult. They need to grow a pair!!!

Topic.Title: Apple should buy Disney (content provider) and charge a monthly subscription fee

Message.Msg: I agree with your sentiment. I obviously would prefer a large stealth buyout without Wall Streets knowledge on the order of $50 - $75 billion. May sound large but the RoR on those shares and existing shares would certainly be positive. I only propose the Disney idea because it is like this firm has become too complacent. This is not an MBA case study (I have an MBA but sometimes grow irritable dealing with them) where you sit around and rehash ideas and analyses for months. This is thereal world and their stock has fallen hugely. Taking advantage of the pullback and / or searching for new ways to create value is important. Management just is not aggressive. Would Steve Jobs really have let Wall Street unleash such a butt kicking without any vigorous public refutation? I feel like he would have lashed out by now. Simply my opinion.

Topic.Title: I've been wrong so many time

Message.Msg: Today is the 3rd gap down on the chart. Typically, this is the final exhaustion gap. If the stock hasn't reached bottom yet it will very in the very near term. Einhorn pulled his lawsuit. He didn't do that because he's a good citizen. He did that because he knows that they will do something with the cash. We'll get the dividend news sometime in the next 3 weeks. And when we do, the stock will rebound to the $480-$500 level. It's just too hard to find 4-5% dividend yield from a company trading at 10x with the potential for huge profit growth going forward. Plus, estimates have come down across the board. This is good. The bar is now low enough for them to beat. No matter how you slice it, this stock is due for a pretty good snap back rally in the next 6-8 weeks.

Message.Title: Credit Suisse cuts estimates
Message.Msg: Apple Hits New 52-Week Low at $429.46 By Tiernan Ray Apple (AAPL) continues to trade lower this morning and briefly touched a new 52-week low at $429.46, before regaining a little ground, currently off $7.49, or 1.7%, at $433.91. There's been no one particular item today to pick out. David Einhorn is going to drop his suit against the company over the treatment in its proxy statement of preferred shares, after Apple agreed to withdraw the proposal, according to Bloomberg's Christie Smythe, citing remarks by the judge in the case. As one sharp-eyed reader noted, Credit Suisse's Kulbinder Garcha this morning reiterated an Outperform rating on Apple, and a $600 price target, while cutting his estimates for the iPhone this year and next, citing three reasons: reasons: 1) We are factoring the likelihood of an iPhone refresh for mid-2013, which will cause a hesitancy effect on demand and cause Apple to keep the supply chain lean; 2) Simultaneously we believe the Samsung Galaxy S4 will launch in mid-March and is likely to gain share in the high-end; and 3) At MWC, we see over 35 smartphone launches from leading OEMs year to date, of which ~70% are aimed at the high-end and ~60% have a screen size larger than iPhone 5 (of over 4″), thereby narrowing the product lead on hardware side. As concerns Mobile World Congress, as I wrote this morning, there continue to be some rather negative remarks about the company from analysts bombarded by news this week from Samsung Electronics and others at the

Topic.Title: The market is going up and AAPL is going down B.S

Message.Msg: Einhorn just dropped his lawsuit. The only real hope for the longs in the short-term was that the company would either boost the dividend payout or buy back shares to increase demand. Einhorn's suit was an attempt to force management to do that and it has now been taken off the table. The stock has a ways to go on the downside. It's still significantly over-owned by institutions. That's many millions of shares that money managers would like to sell - even if they have no intention of getting out of the stock entirely. Short interest is only a few hours worth of trading volume so there's no real buying pressure to be had from that quarter.

Topic.Title: Re:Beginning to admire the shorts

Message.Msg: Short interest in AAPL is microscopic. Nasdaq just released numbers as of 2/15 and it was about 18 million shares short. That's about 5 hours of trading volume and less than 2% of the total shares. http://www.nasdaq.com/symbol/aapl/short-interest#.UTDo3ldWLcw With such small short interest, it's not the shorts driving the stock down. The problem is longs abandoning the name. Institutions like steady top line growth, margin expansion and upside earnings surprises. AAPL has one out of three but has a shareholder base which bought expecting the company to hit on all cylinders. That shareholder base is now shrinking to fit the new reality. Quit blaming vague conspiracies ("the shorts") and take some time to understand what is REALLY driving the stock down.

Message.Title: Expectations
Message.Msg: That is the real problem with Apple. They had 3 blockbuster products in a row with out a serious mis-step during less than a decade. That is virtually unheard of in business. Most companies never even get one such product. The last blockbuster was developed under Steve Jobs in 2008-09. The current management has not show us the ability to innovate like Jobs. That isn't a knock on them; nobody else has either. The financial problem is that customers won't pay a big premium for something better than the competition unless it's radically better. Like nearly everyone else in history, Cook and his team give us incremental product improvement. That is a recipe for profit margins that are closer to the competition when Wall Street has been conditioned to expect margins much higher than everyone else. With margins shrinking back towards industry norms, earnings growth requires revenue to expand faster than margins contract. They were able to do so last quarter but only just barely. What troubles me is that it was the quarter when the biggest product line was refreshed. If phone margins didn't rise when the sales mix was moving from the iPhone 4S to iPhone 5, it's not reasonable to expect margins to grow in the next 2 quarters when there is less of a favorable shift in the sales mix because there won't be a new product introduced.

Topic.Title: Re:Beginning to admire the shorts

Message.Msg: I have no long-term position in Apple. The shareholder base is too volatile and price too unstable for anything more than a swing trade. The problem with the company is MARGINS. They can grow revenue but the big opportunities are in places where they have to cut price to get sales - like China. So they could grow sales by 20% and EPS by 5%. It's a big headwind until those stabilize. And to stabilize margins, they will need either a new blockbuster product or radical innovation on the existing products. All is see is incremental changes with the iPhone 5 and not even that with the iPad Mini. So margins should continue to compress for a couple more quarters at least.

Message.Title: Big boys just make a bunch of money on the short side!
Message.Msg: The trend is down so if one is thinking about going long you may want to wait. This is an excellent trading stock now for the high frequency traders. At present they are making it on the down side. Some big investors have their money already in the stock so limited buyers at present. When the traders cover and go long AAPL will have a nice move up. They could cover at 430, 400 or 350. The last hour of trading for the last few days has not had longs participating so it has been down for a number of days in a row. The traders move the stock and if they are short then there is a lack of buyers. In fact many of the buyers on the bid are just shorts covering. The market is up again while AAPL is down significantly again. A lot of folks have been catching a falling knife and it could keep falling for some time. Wait for it to turn with some volume or you could find yourself down a bundle. They could flush this down 30 dollars in one day so be careful. The big boys over extend on the short side as well as the long side. GLTA and have a great weekend.

Message.Title: Timmy, If you need an example of an exit memo see below
Message.Msg: People of Groupon, After four and a half intense and wonderful years as CEO of Groupon, I've decided that I'd like to spend more time with my family. Just kidding - I was fired today. If you're wondering why... you haven't been paying attention. From controversial metrics in our S1 to our material weakness to two quarters of missing our own expectations and a stock price that's hovering around one quarter of our listing price, the events of the last year and a half speak for themselves. As CEO, I am accountable. You are doing amazing things at Groupon, and you deserve the outside world to give you a second chance. I'm getting in the way of that. A fresh CEO earns you that chance. The board is aligned behind the strategy we've shared over the last few months, and I've never seen you working together more effectively as a global company - it's time to give Groupon a relief valve from the public noise. If there's one piece of wisdom that this simple pilgrim would like to impart upon you: have the courage to start with the customer. My biggest regrets are the moments that I let a lack of data override my intuition on what's best for our customers. This leadership change gives you some breathing room to break bad habits and deliver sustainable customer happiness - don't waste the opportunity! I will miss you terribly. Love, Andrew

Topic.Title: Re:Beginning to admire the shorts

Message.Msg: Fair enough. I just don't see the evidence that there's much of it going on though. When shares are sold (short or otherwise) they tend to drive down price. When they are bought back they tend to drive up price by an equal amount. If there is much day trade shorting going on, the net price impact should be zero for the round-trip which takes place in a single trading session. It would not cause big moves on a closing basis. One other thing you'd see is downward pressure on the stock near the open as they shorted and upward pressure near the close as daytraders covered. AAPL tends to move in the same direction for the day. When it does reverse intraday, it's almost always doing so with the market.

Message.Title: Only 1 of 3 Possible Explanations For This Stock Price
Message.Msg: 1: Management is intentionally letting this stock get hammered so they can provide their employees with stock options, at very attractive pricing, with complete disregard to its shareholders' (very likely); 2: Apple is saving its powder for a very large acquisition (highly unlikely); 3: Apple's management following Steve Jobs' passing is totally incompetent, well beyond anyone's worst expectations (highly likely). There is no other possible explanation for management's total silence throughout this pummeling, or their unwillingness to buy Apple's shares at this low valuation. For the record, I am long, way long. Had way too much respect for Apple's products, and thought that they were bullet proof even to the worst of managers. Guess that I didn't account for Tim Cook's ability to submarine this stock like he has.

Message.Title: Supply Comment #1
Message.Msg: "Sure. Let me take the second part of that first. I think overall our team did just a fantastic job ramping a record number of new products during the quarter. We did have significant shortages due to robust demand on both iPad mini and both models of the iMac that persisted the entire quarter. And we are still short of both of those today as the matter of fact. Additionally, supply of iPhone 5 which short to demand until late in the quarter and iPhone 4 was short for the entire quarter, we believe that we can achieve a supply demand balance on iPad mini during this quarter and on iPhone 4 during this quarter. On iMac, we are confident that we are going to significantly increase the supply, but the demand here is very strong and we are not certain that we will achieve a supply demand balance during the quarter." Seeking Alpha

Zilch, Nada, Nothing. The brain-trust on the Executive Board hasn't been able to figure out what acquisitions they can make to propel the company forward. Granted, Steve is no longer here with his product genius, but there is absolutely no excuse for not being able to figure out how to grow the company in areas other than new product launches. I've been hearing rumors about another or increased dividend in the next couple of weeks, but that's not going to move the needle very far. So in the meantime, here we all sit, hemorrhaging away to new 52 week lows day after day now or week after week. As it is, we're watching a new 52 week low hit every 15 minutes on the day. Message.Title: Apple vs Google food for thought
Message.Msg: If you subtract 100 billion cash from Apples market cap you get 300 billion market cap. That would leave Apple with roughly 40 billion in cash remaining. Google has a little over 40 billion in cash. Google has a market cap slightly over 260 billion today. So with the same net cash you are paying 40 billion more for Apple, but you are getting 4 times the earnings power. Even if Apples earnings fall 25%, which it could, you are still getting 3 times the earnings compared to Google. At current prices for Apples stock I think it makes sense to buy some. I mean, what else are you buying today that's already pricing in a large contraction in earnings and to which that earnings contraction isn't a sure thing?

Topic.Title: i bought at $705

Message.Msg: If you are looking long term, yes you did. I bought 5 years ago around $190. Right after it went down to around $130. Boy! That was nerve-wracking! I've more than doubled my money so it's hard to complain about an annual 20%ish ROI. I'm sure in 5 years, you'll be glad you did. When Apple became the largest company in the world, that's when things started to slide. When anything or anyone becomes #1 in anything, they become more of a target and right now it's hard to find analysts that not part of this bashing frenzy. It's just human nature. I'm not saying that Apple doesn't have some issues to work out but human nature is part of the mix, IMHO.

Topic.Title: C'mon $400

Message.Msg: We are likely to come close. Not today, but soon. The selling has been unrelenting for the last two weeks. Just a daily drift down with a spike down at the end. I see this continuing for awhile as there is no love for the stock, and barring a surprise announcement, no catalysts. In fact, it may go below $400 if the analysts and "journalists" report bogus supply and demand stories prior to the 2Q earnings call.

Message.Title: Sadly.. It's time to do some selling..
Message.Msg: I've been long for a long long time.. still have some profit left, and I'm going to lock it in before it gets worse. After looking at the facts as they can best be seen through all of the secrecy, it's pretty obvious that there are problems with the company.. Maybe big ones on the horizon. I just don't buy that Tim doesn't know what to do. He could share enough to stabilize the stock by being a little more descriptive in the product line timing, or certainly if they were confident in future revenue's they'd get a moster buyback in place and give the stock a jolt, or at least a floor. The fact that the company isn't doing any of this, really means that they are seeing rough seas ahead. It's a great company, but it's cyclical, as most are in tech. My guess is that the "ecosystem' that gets touted will start losing folks to the next better mousetrap. They may also be looking at a large acqusition to try to revive growth. If that happens, it'll be further confirmation that the best days are gone. I"ll hold a few shares, and if there's any panic selling where it goes down another fifty or so, I may pick a few back up short term. Good luck everyone!

Message.Title: The stock slide totally benefits Apple Board Members and Management
Message.Msg: There was no incentive to pay a preemptive dividend in 2012, because the management and board held so few shares...... No benefit to them. They had already cashed out before the slide. Apple knew the magic number for IPhone sales was 50 Million in the first Q, yet they came up shy by only 1.5Million. At that level you could have made the number. They didn't. They did little to defend their sales and profit numbers.... Also did little to explain the supply shortages, was it change in suppliers, quality, miscalculation of estimates..... ? They left that one for the imagination. The numbers were not that bad.......but the presentation was. They changed their guidance process and refused to give EPS estimates...... Knowing this would create angst, and result in a drop. ( 30 points in 20 minutes when it was being explained by the CFO on the conference call) No updates on share buybacks..... Another air ball. In all three public appearances since the January earnings release, the stock went down 75 points as Cook was speaking, and his reaction ......... He does not like it... But has done nothing to show the market they have a plan... And reverse it. No sense of urgency here. It sure looks like, with the help of GS and WS, and the media, they are getting this to a level that takes the pressure off, provides an good entry point for options, lower buybacks or starting point for a LBO..... Really quite bizarre set of events. This will be one for the Harvard Business School case study .

Message.Title: AAPL fiasco is mostly self-inflicted - lackluster leadership by Cook
Message.Msg: Jobs was arrogant but investors put up with that because he was very innovative and he delivered on products. Cook can't follow Jobs model because he failed to innovate and execute and therefore investors have less reason to accept arrogance. AAPL is down 40% and yet it's not attracting investors on dips. Here is what Cook has to do: 1. Split stock 5:1 and increase dividend by at least 10%. 2. Stop being so secret - provide more tangibe proof that he has some exciting products and tell more when they are coming. Vague statements will not do. 3. Smartphone market is saturated and high premium prices can't be sustained. Have to give more product/price choices especially in the emerging market (China, India, Brazil). 4. Hire more engineers and innovate more - without innovation AAPL will go down to $300 rather quickly. 5. Be more responsive to investors - they have a right to know more so they can evaluate if AAPL is a good company to invest in. Past arrogance will not work.

Topic.Title: The stock slide totally benefits Apple Board Members and Management

Message.Msg: I know many managements do this, but I don't think Apples management is intentially doing this. I do believe they don't view the drop with the same sense of urgency as some shareholders do, but that is as it should be. As it stands right now, Apple has a free option to purchase its shares at very attractive prices. If management had talked up the stock to where the price was 500 or 600 still, then we wouldn't have such an option. My advice is to try and understand that the price decline is only temporary and that in a few months it will start to slowly move back to rational pricing, and in the meantime we, the company and shareholders, have free options to buy at more than reasonable prices. This is the best thing that could happen for shareholders in the long run.

Message.Title: Judge knocks 40% off jury's $1.05B verdict in Apple v. Samsung
Message.Msg: Details below. When it is said and done Apple may have to pay Samsung. LOL Watch and Learn Judge Lucy Koh on Friday struck down more than 40 percent of the $1.05 billion in damages a jury awarded to Apple in its patent infringement case against chief rival Samsung. Vanessa Blum, federal courts reporter for The Recorder in San Francisco tweeted on Friday that Judge Koh had struck roughly $440 million off the damage award Apple won in its case against Samsung. Koh has reportedly ordered a new trial for the $440 million. Apple won the award in a sweeping victory at the end of a hotly contested trial. After just 22 hours of deliberation, the jury returned a verdict finding Samsung guilty of infringement on all but one of Apple's asserted patents. Apple had asked for roughly $2.5 billion in damages. Apple, the jury found, had not violated any of the South Korean conglomerate's patents. In the initial ruling, Samsung had been found to be willful in its infringement, which held the possibility of a tripling of the $1.05 billion award.

Topic.Title: People, one time special dividends do zip for a company's stock price.

Message.Msg: In this instance you are largely correct. If the stock were heavily shorted, that would be a completely different story. Short-sellers are responsible for paying the dividends on any shares shorted. Big dividends are a big cash hit to short-sellers and many will buy back before the dividend to avoid the payout.

Message.Title: Apple's Next Big Thing Will Be Huge
Message.Msg: Apple's Next Big Thing Will Be Huge If your company has been going up against Apple Inc. (Nasdaq: AAPL) in the smartphone, tablet PC, or digital music player markets, be very afraid. Apple's return salvo may catch you completely by surprise. The company has been too quiet recently. Ominously quiet. The silence can only mean one thing: Apple will come out soon with another major product line that will redefine its market segment. That's my prediction. How do I know? Apple's late founder, chairman and CEO Steve Jobs promised the company will be rolling out some extraordinary breakthrough technologies in the near future. I believe the process of rolling out the next product from Apple is peaking currently and we should see something compelling from the company within months. In order to continue pacing the competition, Apple has to keep its innovation engine humming. Jobs's demise is unlikely to hamper this, at least not in the short term. All indications are that the company had a batch of products it was working on before his death. Speculations within the industry include an update to the Apple TV box -- some say it might be a conventional TV-support product (miniaturized) with video streaming capabilities. I believe Apple will probably unveil a new device that will unsettle many and redefine the video entertainment industry. It will definitely combine the best of Apple hardware and software with industry content. I am fascinated with the growing speculations in the industry about the next products Apple might introduce for entertainment. These include a Siri or voice-controlled HDTV, an Apple iTV that transforms the television experience -- one that an analyst believes the industry isn't quite prepared for, or a direct invasion of the publishing and educational books market. We may only speculate on what Apple has in mind next, but we can also be certain it won't be another humdrum product. The company's future hangs on its ability to wow the consumer market, r

Topic.Title: Bottom here

Topic.Title: FIRE TIM COOK NOW

Message.Msg: I completely agree. The market excused Steve Jobs because he was Steve Jobs, a man with vision and an incredible track record. Tim Cook is an average CEO at best and is not going to be afforded the same leeway by Wall Street. He is an idiot who has the power to change Wall Street's perception of Apple, but still turns a blind eye. Steve Jobs could say, "we're focused on making great products" and people believed it. Tim Cook thinks that's all he has to say. The problem is that he has ZERO vision, no track record, and is living off the coat tails of Steve Jobs in much the same way as Steve Ballmer is living off the coattails of Bill Gates. But another problem is that the shareholders are gutless to get rid of Cook. The last shareholders meeting was a cheerleading event...

Topic.Title: Bottom here

Message.Msg: " This is the time to buy " Not yet. there's still more investor profits to be taken off the table. This downtrend will continue to the real bottom of the present cycle, which is around 350-375. THEN, a bunch of analyst downgrades have to come. THEN, the stock floats around for a while. All of this while Apple is working on the next generation of products and services, which ultimately will propel the stock BACK UP for a new cycle. THAT"S how it's going to play out. So, look to average in at around 350 or so.

Topic.Title: Bottom here

Message.Msg: This thing will trade in a range of $380 to $480 until 3 quarter. A dividend announce will come shorting and get it back the high-end of the range, but not going to break above $500 without another 2 earnings reports with serious juice in them. I think fair value is just under $500 and that there is no "got to have" products coming. A combination of Div announcement, product release and purchase of major firm (netflix, Hulu, FB, etc.) is that only way it see over $500 soon. Market share can erode over night and everyone knows it. Look no further than Nokia, RImm, and Moto.

Topic.Title: How about a drop of $275 in a bull market over a period of less than 6 months?

Message.Msg: I did this 4 plus years ago when AAPL went from $176.79 in August to $97.07 in September in 2008. That was a 45% loss of stock value in a month. I could not believe it then and here I am again. So, another day of portfolio decimation. And Tim Cook tells us to “… be patient”. The mishandling of the stock crush for 5 months is total incompetence. Similar to the “Cook & Co’s total mishandling of the new iMac launch” which never should have happened. Remember when the new PowerPC delivery delayed the iMac release, Steve Jobs moved the Macs over to the Intel chip. “Apple shareholders should be patient.” Have you ever heard of a lifeguard telling a drowning swimmer to “be patient”, I will get to you someday. REALLY! “be patient”!

Message.Title: Don't underestimate the intelligence of APPLE board
Message.Msg: I think that APPLE board has a plan: #1, they don't want to shoot in the water when the stock was at $500, it would rise to $590 to $610 if they had announced one time special dividend or more shares buyback, but the stock would not stay there, it would go down 2 weeks after announcement. What APPLE board wants is that when they announce dividend increase or buyback, the stock price appreciation would stay and they will give the stock a solid bottom. That's why they have waited. What were they waiting for: AN INSTITUTIONAL DEMAND POINT= $420 It's very possible that some announcement is imminant. Institutional investor support with the announcement will move the stock back to $500 level, and the stock would never go below $420 in future and thus give APPL management credit to set a bottom #, they want to do several shoots one after one: a. announcement of share buyback/dividend b. in a week, China Mobile deal c. two weeks later, I-TV invitation d,....................... That's why .Einhorn now is silent. He's buying more shares. Any suggestion that he will sell at current level is stupid!

Message.Msg: "failed to instill confidence in the brand"? Apple was just rated the most admired company in the world. Steve Jobs did not make a deal with China Mobile either. And Apple has not missed any forecasts. They have exceeded all of their guidance. You are talking about "analysts expectations" which are complete BS anyway. Problems with products. Anyone remember "antennagate" or batteries that catch on fire? As I said, you are equating the stock being down with the company not doing well. The company is doing great. The stock price is "Wall Street"s doing. They liked Apple fine at $650 to $700. It was a great company the view of people like you. Cook was running things then too. And don't kid yourself, Cook has been running Apple long before Jobs resigned both officially (as an appointed temporary CEO) and unofficially when Jobs was clearly too ill to be really running things. You are upset because the stock price is down, but Apple and Cook are doing no worse than they were when the stock was $700. All that has changed is traders' sentiment and that is not within Apple or Cook's control.

Topic.Title: How about a drop of $275 in a bull market over a period of less than 6 months?

Message.Msg: What I find amazing is when people on these boards come to his defense while none of the pundits, analysts or experts has spoken in glowing terms about his handling of this crisis. He strives to find the most sensational adverbs and adjectives to describe the operations and the future of innovation at his company, yet he hardly inspires confidence in any one-other than some of the most blindly loyal sharehoders. Telling the world that you empathize with those in pain without backing that up with solid effort to alleviate their pain--or at least projecting the impression that you really mean it-- is a hollow gesture at best. A publicly-traded company has fundamental responsibilities to its shareholders-meaning it has to proactively engage in protecting their interests. Talking just to give the impression that you are actively involved doesn't cut it. The value of this stock is a product of overblown expectations and whimsical nature of Wall Street, which suggests we have a true crisis on our hands. Who better to take on this monumental task than the company itself? Do their words and actions demonstrate an awareness of the magnitude of this crisis? No. Do they seem transparent enough for the shareholders to either abandon ship or continue to remain royal until the crisis is lifted? I even sense an insidious tendency on their part to show more restraint in providing a meaningful response to the crisis until the stock completely bottoms out and then take some sort of self-serving action. But are they even aware of the consequences of remaining on this neverending path of dismissiveness and indifference?

Apple's Samsung case award cut nearly in half SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Apple Inc. on Friday had its $1.05 billion award from a patent-infringement case with Samsung Electronics nearly cut in half by a U.S. district court judge. The ruling, by judge Lucy Koh in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California, reduced the jury's damages in the case by $450.5 million, to $599 million on the grounds that Samsung deserves a new trial on claims that several of its smartphones violated Apple patents. Apple had been seeking an increase in damages in the case that involves 14 Samsung smartphones. Apple shares were down by $10, or more than 2%, at $431.28 after the ruling was made public.

Message.Title: Doom And Gloom Technicals..Upbeat Fundamentals
Message.Msg: André J. Bakhos, director of market analysis with New York-based Lek Securities, offers up some negative-sounding technicals: The Apple chart never triggered positively with our work since the turndown; now, the relief rally failed and more doom and gloom appear likely. I present the weekly chart first, followed by the daily. The 50-w SMA is beginning a down slope. I could not pluck a positive out of this chart even if I were paid to do so. The daily chart broke the last low of 435 today on a gap down. We are now in the up gap of January 25, 2012. The next key level is 425—and how AAPL trades, that could be in minutes. Not a promising chart. On the other, Laurence Isaac Balter of Oracle Investment Research, who has a Strong Buy on the stock and thinks it's worth $670, observes that Apple executives must buy three times their salary in stock, and that raising the dividend would be a great way for those executives to pay the bank loan interest of 4% to 5% to purchase the shares. From that he deduces the following: Although we are not privy to details, we imagine that a market interest rate loan of 4-5% for an executive to buy 3x their salary in stock is a great deal. But how does one pay the interest on such a loan? The dividend of course. Should Apple increase their pay out to the average S&P 500 ratio of 34%, this would equate to ~$14-15 Billion in annual dividends. A back of the napkin calculation leads us to assign an average S&P dividend multiple (2.2%/$14B= $636B). Throw in some new products, a refresh cycle and we easily get to a $670 target price. Balter also offers the following Apple factoids he's come up with: Of the $858 Billion in Earnings generated by the S&P 500, Apple generates 4.7% of the total. Of the $975 Billion in Free Cash Flow generated by the S&P 500, Apple generates 4.3%. Of the $283 Billion in total dividends paid by the S&P 500, Apple share is 3.5%. Of the $1500 Billion sitting in cash of the S&P 500, Apple has 9.1% of the total. Apple pays

Message.Title: How to move AAPL back to $500?
Message.Msg: Very simple. It's all about supply and demand. AAPL daily volume is only about 14million these days, many shares bought and sold several times. The net buying or selling volume is only less than 10 million or about $4 billion each day. If APPLE just announce $20 billion buyback in next 30 days(about 20 trading days), which will equals to $1 billion net buyback from APPLE. In a $4 billion daily net supply vs demand, a $1 billion extra demand or 25% extra demand will definately tip the balance of supply and demand, will move the stock back to $500 in a weeks or so.

Topic.Title: REALITY --- Read for ALL -- shorts and longs for AAPL -- shareholder meeting, dividends, future of AAPL

Message.Msg: The problem with your post is that shorts are not over aapl at all. the short interest is at 20M and very low. It may have doubled in the past few months from a year earlier but it is still very very low. What you really see here is that institutions are fleeing that stock... never a good sign... and that the retail investors got fooled by all those analysts who issue ridiculous price targets of 700-$1000 just trying to protect their holdings. No matter how much cash AAPL has, reality has caught up with it, that AAPL is just a life style product that goes through the same cycles as other brands. Look at how well Nokia and the Blackberries did... didn't they once rule the mobile market? How fast did that change and someone else took over.... aka AAPL. Don't be surprised if that someone is Samsung and Microsoft with its Win8 products. Its just a matter of time. AAPL will need the cash and the new reality will be a price range below $300.

Message.Title: Why is Tim Cook confident about the future?
Message.Msg: He knows something we all don't know... A great quarter is already in the bag... given! A big dividend / stock buyback / split is on its way... likely! A new product is looming on the horizons... more than likely! It's seldom that you see a CEO as cool as Cook under pressure. He hasn't buckled under the pressure from the Wall Street goons. Instead, he has stayed true to the course and not let all this distract Apple. Let us all hope that better days are in store for Apple bagholders. We can sure use them. However, in the short term, the Street wants to punish Apple stock further it seems. Who knows where the bottom is. All the longs can hope for is a great quarter, a big dividend, and a new innovation. If that happens, the rest will fall in place.

Topic.Title: Why is Tim Cook confident about the future?

Message.Msg: Cook begins talking about the company's stock price: "I don't like it either," he said. "Neither does the board or management — where the stock trades now vs a few months ago -- but we're focused on the long term." Cook says Apple has some great stuff coming. He said the company is "seriously considering" returning cash to shareholders Wednesday at the company's annual shareholder in Cupertino, Ca. First question: What are you going to do about Android and Samsung gaining market share? Cook: We're not constraining our investment in R&D by a desire to grow a cash pile. We stay very focused and work on a few things. ... The real market share numbers are hard to come by. ... It is clear that Android is on a lot of phones ... it is probably true that iOS is on a lot more tablets .... Success is not making the most. ... Where market share is important (is in being big enough to attract an ecosystem) .... We're really aware of the competition as well. "We don't have our heads stuck up ... stuck in the sand. .... There's a button or two we could press to make the most .... That would not be good for Apple."

Message.Title: Incompetence of Apple Board of Directors
Message.Msg: Apple has the unique problem of trying to figure out how to use $137 billion of cash. Poor Apple! As a shareholder, I find it astounding that Apple STILL doesn't have a plan (at least publicly) as to how to use the funds to benefit shareholders. What is the Board waiting for? Until the company has $200 billion in cash? One would have thought that Tim Cook would have had some information to reveal as to this issue at or before the shareholders' meeting, yet it just wasn't so. Excluding cash, Apple is now trading at a ridiculous low valuation for its business given its profitability. But, the financial engineers at Apple have no excuse for this debacle. What is the CFO doing about this cash "problem?" Apparently, still thinking. Unless the Board is completely immune to shareholder concerns, I would hope that very, very soon, Apple will have a plan, or even a part of a plan.

Topic.Title: How accurate is Peter Misek from Jefferies ? Why does he change his Price targets so frequently?

Message.Msg: Bottom line is that it makes him look less stupid to say $500 than $900. Analysts are like Zebras who always eat grass together in a pack....there is green grass nearby but an individual zebra won't go to it alone because he might get eaten by a lion. In the same way, Analysts don't want to stray from the consensus of their "pack" too much because if they are wrong, they will get ridiculed. If everybody is wrong together it makes one person less culpable.

Message.Title: Relax longs...
Message.Msg: Isn't there an old saying about the stock market, "be fearful when others are greedy; be greedy when others are fearful." Just a few months ago, WS was cheer leading Apple's rally. You heard stuff like "first trillion dollar company," "$1000 price target," etc. Funds and individual investors were afraid of being left behind in buying Apple shares. Too much money was piled into the stock in too short a period of time. Today it looks like another universe. You hear doom and gloom day after day, and you see shorts come out of everywhere like maggots crawl from beneath the rocks. It's unfortunate for those who bought too high, but it will be equally unfortunate for those who short when there isn't much downside room left. We all know how WS works - they generate gains by pushing stocks up and down, attracting smaller money to follow. Once the buying(selling) is exhausted, they flip the board and start making money on the other side. We know Apple is a great company with profitable business. In the last 5, 6 months, nothing about the company's prospects has materially changed. The stock has been trading mostly on sentiment rather than fundamentals. After 6 months of selling, shorts appear to be euphoric, and the resentment toward Apple from longs has become stronger than never before. It is often said when things look so abysmal that even the firmest longs start to waver, the bottom is close and it's time to buy. This has been proven to be true with many other companies with much weaker financial strength. With Apple, the upward reward is much greater than the downside risk around this point. Just analyze Apple's financial statements! Their assets are growing. PPEs are getting bigger. Earnings are stellar. And they outspend any other company on R&D, which is a particularly good sign boding more growth down the road.
